Q13: When the objective has an outcome on the game in relation to lore or events.
Q14: I feel motivated to achieve the objective to see the outcomes and effects it has on the game upon completion. E.g. in FFXIII-3, an optional mission to kill every single monster till there was 1 left of its kind caused a shiny stronger version to appear as it was the last one before extinction. You also unlocked an additional dungeon for doing so.

Q13: The anticipation of a reward (can be satisfaction or narrative real)
Q14: As someone who likes to play hard games I am often driven by the anticipation of how I will feel once the objective is completed, which is often satisfaction after having completed it after a number of attempts. In this case I know I’m going to get a reward and expect it will be worth the effort. Implying there will be a reward is sufficient provided it’s one I anticipate is worth the effort. If the game or series has delivered outcomes I find satisfyingly in the past I am more likely to have high anticipation of the reward.
Q15: Having a mage rush to the frontline threw me and my strategy, which kind of made me forget about the ritual and focus on defeating the enemy before they killed the mages. I think potentially having a reminder of the time limit after a few rounds would probably make sure players wouldn’t do this and could also increase the sense of urgency.

Q2: I've played through the first tutorial
Q13: I tend to complete almost every objective presented to me by a game, and this is often in the form of clear (often measurable) directives—collect this thing, find this person, your average side quest kind of stuff. Personally, and I think it's just a quirk of mine, I tend to be a little demotivated by vague, more exploratory objectives. The other crucial thing of course is that the objective is rewarding - an upgrade, a new item, a bit of narrative that you otherwise wouldn't see, all those things can of course make for an appealing objective.
Q14: Some simple objectives I would describe as mundanely as a satisfying errand, one that I can complete with a certain degree of proceduralness, which I often find relaxing. Other, more world-building objectives I would describe as high stakes, emotional (say, for example, escaping the underworld in Hades), and well-justified by the plot.
